chapter.summary: Management of weight loss in the first days after birth which may be normal (most cases) or due to underlying factors requiring further assessment and intervention.

Scenario: Weight loss after the early days of life
Weight loss is in the first few days after birth
subChapters.htmlHeader: Weight loss in the first few days after birth
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• In all cases:
    • Liaise with other healthcare professionals involved in care (such as the midwife/health visitor) to ensure that all concerns are identified.
    • Identify and discuss specific parental/carer concerns.
  • If weight loss is less than 10% of birth weight in the early days of life and assessment is normal:
    • Reassure the parent/carer that:
      • It is common for infants to lose some weight during the early days after birth and this is usually associated with fluid adjustments.
      • This weight loss usually stops after about 3 or 4 days of life.
      • Most infants will return to their birth weight by 3 weeks of age.
    • Ensure the parent/carer has adequate feeding support from an appropriately trained healthcare professional (usually the midwife/health visitor).
      • Be aware that supplementary feeding with infant formula in a breastfed infant may help with weight gain, but can result in the cessation of breastfeeding.
      • If breastmilk is supplemented with formula the mother should be supported to continue breastfeeding, advised to express breast milk to promote milk supply, and feed the infant with available breast milk before giving infant formula.
    • Arrange follow up to monitor growth at appropriate intervals — no more often than daily in infant is less than 1 month old.
      • Record all measurements in the parent or carer-held Personal Child Health Record.
    • Signpost to sources of further information and support.  Patient information is available from:
      • NHS Pregnancy and Baby guide.
      • The UK breastfeeding network.
  • If weight loss is more than 10% of birth weight in the early days of life or the infant has not returned to their birth weight by 3 weeks of age:
    • Refer to/discuss with paediatrics, with urgency dependant on the clinical situation, all infants:
      • With symptoms or signs suggestive of an acute or chronic underlying condition.
      • With rapid weight loss or severe under-nutrition.
      • With safeguarding concerns — for further information see the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management.
      • With slow linear growth or unexplained short stature.
      • Who have not responded to management in primary care.
    • Ensure that parents/carers have adequate feeding support from an appropriately trained healthcare professional (usually the midwife/health visitor).
      • Consider direct observation of feeding by a person with appropriate training and expertise.
      • Be aware that supplementary feeding with infant formula in a breastfed infant may help with weight gain, but can result in the cessation of breastfeeding.
      • If a breastmilk is supplemented with formula the mother should be supported to continue breastfeeding, advised to express breast milk (to promote milk supply), and advised to give available breast milk before infant formula.
    • Arrange follow up:
      • Weight should be measured again at appropriate intervals (no more than once daily if less than 1 month old) — record all measurements in the parent or carer-held Personal Child Health Record.
      • If an infant with faltering growth develops new clinical symptoms or signs after the initial assessment, develops marked weight loss or fails to respond to feeding support consider referral to paediatrics.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of weight loss is in the first few days after birth are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth [NICE, 2015] and Faltering Growth – recognition and management [NICE, 2017] and expert opinion in review articles [Wright, 2010; Homan, 2016; Larson-Nath, 2016; Gonzalez-Viana, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].

Weight loss in the first few days of life
  • The NICE guideline on Faltering Growth – recognition and management [NICE, 2017] considers weight loss in the first few days of life separately to inadequate weight gain in older infants and children:
    • Some weight loss in the first days after birth is normal and usually associated with body fluid adjustments [NICE, 2017].
    • However, if assessment reveals abnormal/concerning features, further assessment and intervention is required [NICE, 2017].
Early weight loss
  • The recommendations that birth weight should typically be regained by 3 weeks of age and that a threshold of 10% weight loss in the first few days after birth should be used to identify infants where weight is a cause for concern is taken from the NICE guideline on Faltering growth [NICE, 2017].
    • For a full description of the evidence used in the generation of this recommendation see the full NICE guideline available at www.nice.org.uk.
  • Expert opinion in a review article is that most babies lose some weight in the few days after birth. Studies in healthy infants suggest that only 3–7% of children lose as much as 10% of birth weight and most regain their birth weight by the age of 2 weeks [Wright, 2010].
Importance of involving the multidisciplinary team (MDT)
  • Expert opinion in guidelines and review articles agrees on the importance of involvement of the MDT (for example midwife, health visitor, dietitian, social worker, lactation specialist, paediatrician) in assessment and management of faltering growth [Block, 2005; Homan, 2016; NICE, 2017].
